summary: An interview with Tancred Dyke-Wells, creative director of Battalion Wars, exploring his career and the game's development.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen, followed by a scene from a video game featuring a blue armored vehicle navigating a sandy terrain with trees and wooden fences in the background. The vehicle is equipped with various weapons and is accompanied by smaller vehicles. The game interface displays a compass, health bar, and icons representing different weapons and abilities. The armored vehicle moves forward, engaging in combat with enemy units, and the player's health and weapon status are updated accordingly. The scene transitions to a webpage titled "Battalion Wars," featuring an interview with Tancred Dyke-Wells, the Creative Director of the game. The webpage includes a photo of Tancred, a fan art illustration, and a written message from him expressing gratitude to the fans and discussing the game's history and future. The video concludes with a black screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker introducing himself and the topic, an interview related to Battalion Wars. The speaker mentions community member "Fan Battalion" and Tankrid Dykwels, the creative director of Battalion Wars, and the interview being interesting for fans. The clip transitions to what seems like an introduction sting with music, possibly from the Battalion Wars soundtrack, which has a playful, possibly cartoon-like style and has the sound of drums.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a static image of a webpage titled "Written Interview with Tancred Dyke-Wells (Creative Director of Battalion Wars)." The page is designed with a white background and includes two circular images at the top: one of Tancred Dyke-Wells, the Creative Director, and another of a character from the game Battalion Wars. Below these images, there is a message from Tancred Dyke-Wells, expressing gratitude to the Battalion Wars fan community for their support and love for the game. The message also mentions the 30 playable modes on the Nintendo Switch and the privilege of being interviewed. The date of the message is noted as June 20, 2022. The overall atmosphere of the webpage is professional and appreciative, with a focus on the game's community and its creative director. There are no visual changes or movements between frames, maintaining a consistent presentation of the webpage throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one person, presumably Tankred, sending greetings, expressing gratitude to the "Battalion Wars fan community", and marveling at their continued enthusiasm for the game. This message is spoken in a heartfelt and appreciative tone. He mentions "3D printed models" and "tournaments," and shares he has told former producers at Nintendo about them. There is music playing in the background which is upbeat, electronic and synth-heavy, and reinforces the positive tone of the clip. The speaker then notes it is a privilege to be interviewed.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a green toy tank on a beige surface, followed by a series of colorful toy tanks in green, orange, blue, and white, each with distinct designs and features. The camera then shifts to a blue toy airplane with multiple propellers, placed on a dark surface, showcasing its intricate details. The scene transitions to a collection of various toy tanks and ships in different colors, including orange, white, blue, and purple, arranged on a wooden surface. The video then focuses on two small figurines, one blue and one white, each holding a large weapon, standing on a dark surface with a blue toy vehicle in the background. The final frame displays a webpage titled "1^st Part: FanBattalion Questions," featuring an introduction to the world of video games, a brief biography of the author, and links to related content, including an interview and a game development series. The webpage also includes a section on the author's current projects and a call to action to support them on platforms like Steam and Twitter.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing familiarity with 3D printed models made by someone named Benton, whom he highly recommends, describing them as "super cool." His tone is enthusiastic. The speaker then announces a shift to "part one, fan battalion questions."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a webpage titled "1^Part: FanBattalion Questions" displayed on a computer screen, featuring an introduction about the interviewee's career in video game development, specifically mentioning his work on the Art Academy series. The page includes images of the Art Academy DS and DSi games, a photo of the interviewee, and links to an interview and his social media profiles. The scene transitions to a close-up of a hand holding a tablet, displaying the same webpage, with a blurred background suggesting an indoor setting. The video then shifts to a close-up of a digital painting application on a handheld device, showcasing a virtual artist's palette with various colors and brushes, indicating the user's engagement in digital art creation. The final frame shows a close-up of the handheld device's screen, focusing on the digital painting application, with the device's buttons visible on the right side, emphasizing the user's interaction with the art tools.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with someone asking an introductory question. The speaker is curious about the person's career in the video game world, specifically their role in the development of "Battalion Wars." A male then responds, stating he has been working in video games professionally for over 25 years and has shipped around 24 titles as an artist, game designer, lead artist, designer, and creative director. He adds he is probably best known for directing the "Art Academy" series for Nintendo and that it was a real career high to be interviewed about that by Satoru Iwata. He ends, noting he hasn't played the "Art Academy" games, but knows they were popular for a while. A moment of silence then occurs.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a webpage featuring an article about a person named Alex, who has worked in the video game industry for over 25 years. The article includes a photo of Alex and mentions their roles as an artist, game lead, lead artist, designer, and creative director. The webpage also contains links to interviews and a blog post. The scene transitions to gameplay footage from a video game, showcasing a character navigating through various levels, including a village, a fiery environment, and a dark, eerie setting. The gameplay footage is overlaid on the webpage, creating a layered effect. The video then shifts to a close-up of the gameplay, focusing on the character's movement and interactions within the game environment. The character, labeled "P1," is seen traversing through different terrains, such as a lava-filled area and a dark, mystical landscape. The video concludes with the character continuing to navigate through the game, highlighting the dynamic and immersive nature of the gameplay experience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with speech, presumably from a male speaker who mentions having an indie studio alongside a business partner. He says they are "Cinder Cone Games" and are making a "colorful, fun action title" called "Skeleton Crew", inviting listeners to check it out. The speaker's tone is casual and promotional. He then promises to check out the game in response.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a text document discussing the development of a game called "Battlefront Wars." The document mentions the game's concept, its evolution, and the team's efforts to create a technical action game. The text is accompanied by images of the game's cover art for the Wii and PC platforms, showcasing vibrant, cartoonish graphics with characters in futuristic military attire. The scene transitions to gameplay footage from "Battlefront Wars," set in a desert environment with a military theme. The player controls a character in a blue armored suit, engaging in combat with enemy units. The interface displays a mini-map, health bar, and various icons, indicating the game's real-time strategy elements. The player uses a bazooka to attack enemy vehicles, with on-screen text reading "Greetings, Frontier dogs! KOMMANDER UBEL is here!" The video captures the action-packed gameplay, highlighting the game's mechanics and the immersive desert battlefield setting.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the "Battalion Wars" project, highlighting it as a group effort involving talented people. He mentions his role in directing those games, starting with an original idea. He describes the core concept as a tactical action game that allows players to give commands to other units. He expresses his initial desire for an action game with more depth and acknowledges the ambitious nature of hybridizing genres. The audio concludes with a sound resembling a mechanical or impact noise.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a screenshot of a video game interface, featuring a character in blue armor standing in a desert-like environment with a radar and various game controls visible. The scene transitions to a close-up of a document with text and images of game covers, discussing the game's development and design. The next scene shows a tank in a war-torn area with smoke and explosions in the background, followed by a group of soldiers in combat gear moving through a dusty, urban environment. The soldiers are seen engaging in combat, with one soldier lying on the ground, possibly injured or dead. The video then shifts to a first-person perspective of a player navigating through a dark, industrial corridor, with a message on the screen indicating a high ping of 268. The player is then shown in a squad management interface, selecting units for deployment. The final scene returns to the desert environment, where the player's squad, dressed in blue armor, is advancing towards enemy forces, engaging in combat with rifles and other weapons. The video captures various aspects of the game, including character movement, combat scenarios, and strategic planning.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker recalling his time as a lead artist for a game based on the movie "Reign of Fire", mentioning their team playing Battlefield 1942 at lunch. He shifts to discussing Battlefield: Bad Company 2 and how the older Battlefield games included a commanding officer role as a unit on the field, explaining its special privileges in multiplayer. The speaker then makes a transition back to discussing the interview.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a video game set in a desert environment, featuring a character in blue armor engaging in combat. The character is seen wielding a bazooka, as indicated by the text "BAZOOKA" on the screen, and is actively attacking enemy structures and vehicles. The game interface displays various elements, including a minimap, health bars, and a text overlay that provides context and narrative to the gameplay. The text overlay includes phrases such as "CAPTURE POINT" and "ASSAULT," suggesting objectives and missions within the game. The character's actions are dynamic, with explosions and gunfire effects adding to the intensity of the scene. The environment is detailed with sandy terrain, scattered rocks, and distant mountains, creating a realistic and immersive setting. The video captures the essence of a strategic combat game, emphasizing the player's role in achieving objectives and overcoming challenges.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker musing about "an action game...with NPC allies," reflecting on the challenges of blending genres, stating "mashing a couple together is something to attempt at your peril." He transitions to a positive outlook, asserting they created "an original tactical action game." His tone is conversational and reflective. Simultaneously, there is ambient music with an upbeat and adventurous feel, likely intended to highlight the excitement of gaming.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a document titled "Hampton Wars," featuring two game covers for the Wii console. The text discusses the game's development, mentioning the team's work on technical action games and the inspiration drawn from various sources, including "Black 2012 Dragons" and "Taskmaster." The narrative highlights the challenges faced in creating a unique action game and the eventual decision to focus on a different style. The scene transitions to a first-person shooter game, where the player navigates through a war-torn environment, engaging in combat with enemies. The player's health and ammunition are displayed on the screen, and the environment is filled with debris and military equipment. The video then shifts back to the document, which continues to discuss the game's development, mentioning the influence of "Metal Slug" and the team's efforts to create a unique style. The narrative emphasizes the team's passion and dedication to the project. The final scene transitions to a first-person perspective of a vehicle driving through a tunnel, with the player's name "PRIVATE XTG" displayed on the screen. The video concludes with the player navigating through the tunnel, showcasing the game's immersive environment and dynamic gameplay.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker recounting an opportunity he had to put together a demo. Speaking in a casual tone, he describes the creation of the demo, involving soldiers, vehicles, and the use of a PS2 engine. He mentions full spectrum warrior, band of brothers, and a few other "worms eye view tactical command games." Then, he shifts focus to a unique control transfer feature that later appeared as "hot swapping" in the Battlefield series. The speaker mentions recalling seeing a Battlefield game with this feature at a friend's house. The audio ends with the speaker stating that the feature "definitely gives off Battalion Wars vibes."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a document containing text, which is then followed by a scene from a video game featuring a tank-like vehicle shooting blue projectiles in a dark, industrial environment. The next scene shows a tank navigating a snowy landscape, avoiding explosions and obstacles. The video then transitions back to the document, displaying more text, before shifting to another video game scene where a character in green navigates a rocky terrain, using a shield to interact with the environment. The character is seen climbing a wall and exploring a lush, tropical area with palm trees and a body of water in the background. Throughout the video, the text on the document is in English, discussing topics related to game design and development, with phrases like "Control Transfer Feature" and "Battlefront World" visible. The video alternates between the document and the video game scenes, creating a narrative that connects the written content with the gameplay experiences.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing the influence of Metal Slug on his work, mentioning 2D platform action games and art style concepts. He then expresses his appreciation for the Metal Slug games, especially the first few, and notes similarities between their vehicle designs and those of Battalion Wars. The speaker also observes that the infantry in Metal Slug remind him of the grunts in Battalion Wars. He continues by reflecting on the gaming landscape before mobile games and a specific "Clash of Clans art style," noting that a colorful and cartoony aesthetic could have hurt Battalion Wars' reception at the time. Recalling the Wind Waker backlash, the speaker mentions people preferring "gritty and real" aesthetics. Ultimately, he states his personal appreciation for Battalion Wars' art style.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a text document displayed on a computer screen, featuring a detailed narrative about the creation of a game concept and the development process. The text is in English, with a focus on the author's role in designing characters and the game's universe. The background is dark, highlighting the white text on the screen. The scene then transitions to a video game interface, where a character is seen in a combat scenario. The game's HUD (Heads-Up Display) is visible, showing various game elements such as a mini-map, health bar, and ammunition count. The text overlay in the game reads, "The pretty explosions are like fireworks on Xylvania Day... But wait?? Those are Vlad's favorite missile! Nooooot!" and "Boom! Now all you gotta do is capture the COMMUNICATIONS TOWER and the FUEL REFINERY!" The game environment is a desert-like setting with structures and vehicles, and the character is engaged in combat, aiming a weapon at an enemy. The video then returns to the text document, continuing the narrative about the game's development, with the same dark background and white text. The text discusses the author's experience and the collaborative effort involved in creating the game. The video concludes with a return to the game interface, showing the character in a different combat scenario, with the HUD and text overlay providing context for the gameplay. The environment remains consistent with the desert setting, and the character is actively engaged in the game's objectives.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by listing his roles in game development, including "lead designer and art director", as well as concept artist and script supervisor. He describes his work on the sequel, where he was listed as creative director and created concept art and early models for characters, as well as designing troops and writing the original document. He goes on to explain the extent of his role in the development, noting that he supervised voice recording sessions, assisted with casting, and gave direction to the music composer and sound effects designer. He emphasizes that everyone on that team was incredibly passionate and skilled and goes on to admit he was mentally stretched on the project, but loved it.
